title: 114_hr3279
content: The Act is titled the "Open Book on Equal Access to Justice Act" and modifies provisions related to equal access to justice. The "Open Book on Equal Access to Justice Act" amends Section 504 of title 5, United States Code, regarding agency proceedings. It requires the Chairman of the Administrative Conference of the United States to report annually to Congress on fees and expenses awarded under this section. The "Open Book on Equal Access to Justice Act" mandates the Chairman of the Administrative Conference to report annually to Congress on fees and expenses awarded in agency proceedings. The report must include all payments made under settlement agreements, regardless of confidentiality provisions. The Chairman is required to maintain this reporting for a year after the final report submission. The "Open Book on Equal Access to Justice Act" requires the submission of a final report on fees and expenses awarded in agency proceedings. An online searchable database must contain information on each award, including case name, agency involved, claims description, party names, award amount, and basis for finding agency position not justified. The database cannot disclose information prohibited by law or court order. The head of each agency must provide requested information to the Chairman of the Administrative Conference to comply with reporting requirements. The Chairman must submit an annual report to Congress on fees and expenses awarded in agency proceedings, detailing the awards, claims, and relevant information. The report on fees and expenses awarded in agency proceedings must include all payments made under settlement agreements, regardless of confidentiality provisions. The Chairman of the Administrative Conference will identify amounts paid from section 1304 of title 31 for each case in the annual report to Congress. The report must include amounts paid for judgments, fees, and expenses, as well as the statute under which the lawsuit was filed. The Chairman of the Administrative Conference will maintain a searchable database with case details and agency names for awards of fees and expenses. The report must include details such as the party identified in the court document, description of claims, amount of the award, and basis for finding agency position not justified. The online database cannot disclose prohibited information by law. Agencies must provide information to the Chairman of the Administrative Conference as required. Amendments are made to Section 2412 of title 28, United States Code. Amendments are made to Section 2412 of title 28, United States Code, with changes in subsections (d)(3) and (e). The effective date for these amendments applies to awards of fees and expenses made after the enactment of the Act, with initial reports due by March 31 of the following calendar year. The online databases required by section 504(f) of title 5, United States Code, and section 2412(d)(6) of title 28, United States Code, must be established soon after the enactment of this Act, but no later than the deadline for the first reports under the respective sections. Passed by the House of Representatives on November 30, 2015. Attest: KAREN L. HAAS, Clerk.
